column2: 35-44 on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $5$5$5$I've been on this medicine for over 5 years.  It has been so successful that all of my other medications are designed around it.  I will NOT stop taking it.  It's quieted my mind
column4: no more songs stuck in my head for weeks.  I do take this with another mood stabilizer but I've been on this one much longer.  I couldn't function without it.  I've recommended it to family and a few other people.  All have had good experiences. When I started taking this medicine I
column6: noticed a real difference in my personality and my moods.  This is the first medicine to make me feel human again.  I love it.

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Caregiver) $5$5$5$My 6 yr old son has hemi-paritic CP and seizures caused by underdevelopment of his brain due to an inter-uterine stroke.  At age 8 mos we 1st saw him seize and his condition was diagnosed (although I noticed weakness in his right limbs from birth).  He was first put on phenobarbitol.  That worked for about 12 mos.  Then triliptal for abt a yr.  Then we did the Ketogenic Diet for 6 mos.  It stopped the seizures very well!
column3: but was difficult to maintain.  After a cpl yrs of no meds he started having seizures again. Zonisamide worked for about a yr before more break-through seizures started.  Now we give him 50 mg Lamictal morning and night along with 200 mg Zonisamide with 10 ml liquid melatonin at night.  So far it's going good.  Only 2 seizures since we started Lamictal and they were unusually mild and easy to stop. SUCCESS!!  Our Pediatric neurologist warned us of the allergic reaction and b/cuz of that we've built up to this dose very slowly and will continue til we reach the therapeutic dose
column4: then hopefully ween him off the Zonisamide which we suspect is causing aggressive behavior
column5: especially at school.  I wonder however
column6: if my son's apparent inability to keep his hands to himself may be a symptom of ADD or ADHD (both of his parents
column8: and many of his aunts and uncles have ADD/ADHD).  That aside
column9: lamictal seems to be working well for him right now.

column2: 13-18 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $3$2$4$"I am a 15 year-old boy currently taking 2; 100 mg tabs of Lamotrigine (Lamictal) a day. My symptoms are as followed;

column1: i.e. obsessively rethinking my thoughts of things I have problems with
column4: and what I feel I need to say to others.

column1: -More apt to become instantly frustrated and angry at the person/or persons I have a difficulty with.
-Depression symptoms have increased drastically. Although suicidal behavior is almost non-existant (due to the many 'eye-opening' hospitalization experiences)

column2: I cry intensly and obsessively think of my problems. These emotions seem to be short-lived and change surprisingly often. (Currently
column3: I am undignosed with neither Bi-polar (manic-depression) or any other anger problems. I am dignosed with ADHD and a severe manic- depression disorder. I show traits of Borderline and Histrionic Personality disorders. my Doctors seems to be stumpted on what to do
column4: seeing as I've been on just about every medication. So we're trying one of our last hopes

column1: -My mood seems to be de-stablizing as I continue to take Lamictal. I dont Know whether or not it has anything to do with the concerta I recently started but my advice
column2: If it means much coming from a very emotionally conflicted teen-age boy
column3: but I advise great caution when taking this medication
column4: especially when starting it. Severe side effects can occur. It is a anti-seizure medication
column5: newly used as a mood-stablizer medication. Obviously you have to be carefully prescribed this medication by a professional
column6: and you cannot miss doses. It can directly affect your circulatory and heart (cardio) systems.

column1: I highly recommend talking to your doctor
column2: as I have an appointment next week. Im going to tell my doctor all of my symptoms
column3: and so should you. If you are having negative symptoms with this medication. DO NOT give up hope on recovery

7$Condition: Bipolar Depression$12/12/2008 8:19:17 AM$Reviewer: 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient) $4$3$4$Placed on Lamictal for treatment of symptoms of Bipolar, and did see some changes, mainly in aggressive behavioral and quick to react to threatening situations. Insurance suggested a generic, and the first time I took the generic I started loosening my balance, dizziness and degrading concentration. Symptoms repeated the next day as I was asked to again see if I was reacting to the generic. Returned to the non-generic and symptoms never returned. Now insurance company refuses to pay for non-generic drug. What’s a person to do?
